body:
**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

OK so far the failure is in 3.7.6.3 (from 2011) but not in 3.8.3 (from 2014).   narrowing further

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

still building 3.7.15.2 but I'm going to guess this is "Enhance the query optimizer to exploit transitive join constraints. " listed in 3.7.16 at http://sqlite.org/changes.html.

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

yup error is in 3.7.15.2, so 3.7.16 is the version

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- documenation updates to clarify specific SQLite versions
that have problems with right-nested joins and UNION column keys;
references #3633 references #3634.   backport from 1.1 to 0.9
announcing 1.1 as where these behaviors will be retired based
on version-specific checks
- fix test_resultset so that it passes when SQLite 3.10.0 is
present, references #3633


→ 89fa08792e98

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- documenation updates to clarify specific SQLite versions
that have problems with right-nested joins and UNION column keys;
references #3633 references #3634.   backport from 1.1 to 0.9
announcing 1.1 as where these behaviors will be retired based
on version-specific checks
- fix test_resultset so that it passes when SQLite 3.10.0 is
present, references #3633

(cherry picked from commit 89fa08792e98b9e31452aa3c949d9b909b10e7cd)


→ 9cc769ac4004

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- documenation updates to clarify specific SQLite versions
that have problems with right-nested joins and UNION column keys;
references #3633 references #3634.   backport from 1.1 to 0.9
announcing 1.1 as where these behaviors will be retired based
on version-specific checks
- fix test_resultset so that it passes when SQLite 3.10.0 is
present, references #3633

(cherry picked from commit 89fa08792e98b9e31452aa3c949d9b909b10e7cd)


→ dc4eb7904e22

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

- The workaround for right-nested joins on SQLite, where they are rewritten
as subqueries in order to work around SQLite's lack of support for this
syntax, is lifted when SQLite version 3.7.16 or greater is detected.
fixes #3634
- The workaround for SQLite's unexpected delivery of column names as
``tablename.columnname`` for some kinds of queries is now disabled
when SQLite version 3.10.0 or greater is detected.
fixes #3633


→ 9d9fc93b7065

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **status** to closed

issue.title: remove join rewriting for older sqlite versions
issue.body:
Running a centos 7.0 docker container, Python is at version 2.7.5 and the sqlite3 version is:

Python 2.7.5 (default, Jun 17 2014, 18:11:42) 
[GCC 4.8.2 20140120 (Red Hat 4.8.2-16)] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import sqlite3
>>> sqlite3.sqlite_version
'3.7.17'


this is newer than the [3.7.16](https://www.sqlite.org/changes.html) required for direct support of right-nested joins so it seems likely that this rather complex pile of code is not being used anywhere, as SQLAlchemy only supports Python 2.7 and above.  centos6 has only python 2.6 (not supported) and no Python 3.
